author: Staff Reporter
text:
More than 1,000 government employees from various unions affiliated to Tamil Nadu Government Employees Association (TNGEA), staged a protest near the premises of the Collector’s office on Monday in a show of strength as their State-wide indefinite strike entered the sixth day.

M. Gnanathambi, State Treasurer of TNGEA, said that from Monday, Tamil Nadu Primary Teachers’ Association had joined the protest and more associations were expected to join the protest in the coming days.

He denied rumours about some of the associations withdrawing from the protest. “A particular association of Anganwadi workers with affiliation to the ruling party was asked by TNGEA to withdraw from the protest. All other associations are still involved in the strike. Other Anganwadi association members are planning to participate in protests along with their families from tomorrow,” he said.

TNGEA office bearers said that, from Tuesday, non-teaching staff associations of government aided colleges were also joining the protest. They said the ministerial staff associations in Police Department may also join the protest in coming days.

Hopeful

The protesters said that they are hopeful of a favourable announcement from the Tamil Nadu government during the release of interim budget on Tuesday.

TNGEA has begun the indefinite strike demanding the fulfilment of their 20-point charter of demands, which include the removal of new pension scheme, regularising the contract employees in various departments and putting an end to outsourcing of government jobs and recruitment of employees on contractual and consolidated pay basis.
title: TNGEA steps up protest as strike enters sixth day
